summary: what is killing eve about? I never hear/see anything for that show unless on tumblr?
question: what is killing eve about? I never hear/see anything for that show unless on tumblr?
answer:
Wow that is interesting, because that show got mad popular during its run! Notably it gained viewers steadily each week, lots of them, which is practically unheard of these days and people in the industry were sure sitting up and taking notice! I literally just googled “Killing Eve gaining viewers” and the entire first page was all different news articles on this, but here’s the general idea.

Piling up more viewers like that always owes a lot to word-of-mouth, which was clearly STRONG. Which is likely because this show is FUN. It’s a classic cat-and-mouse spy thriller with a whimsically brutal flirty assassin being chased by a relatable™ yet brilliant (& obsessed) detective, developed by Phoebe Waller-Bridge and starring Sandra Oh and Jodie Comer. People were excited because rarely are TV shows of this genre created by a woman with women in the title roles, and then they were excited that it was actually really stylish and gay and good! Killing Eve ended up a huge hit for BBC America, something like their most popular streaming series ever, and was nominated for two Emmys, writing and an acting nod for Sandra Oh.

Basically yeah it’s great you should check it out if you like this kind of thing!

tags: i guess what i like is tv shows that focus on grief lol
title: I’m watching TV
body:
Here’s all my opinions on the TV I’ve been recently consuming:

Wanderlust: This is the only other show I’ve seen, besides My Mad Fat Diary, that accurately captures what therapy is like. I tried to watch that bad Netflix show w/Naomi Watts called Gypsy where she played a therapist and I was like, the writers of this show have certainly never been to therapy and maybe even are unclear on what the concept of a therapy is. I liked that Wanderlust was about grief and long term relationships and polyamory without taking too hard a pro/con stance on anything. The main couple were very believable as a real couple.

Killing Eve: Killing Eve wants me to love it so bad. The BBC wants me to love it so bad. It is the world’s thirstiest show. I thought I’d be really into it because Phoebe Waller-Bridge wrote it and Fleabag was very meaningful for me. But I honestly don’t know what the big deal is. It’s, like, fine. Sandra Oh is a likable presence. Jody Comer certainly has cornered the market on hateful but hot protagonists, I guess. It’s like a dumb cops and robbers type show to put on while I eat dinner on my couch when I’m tired, it’s about that level for me.

Bodyguard: I wrote about this already a few weeks ago, but briefly, way to take an engaging, empathetic opening, then waste six hours of my life by turning it into a “twist” in the last ten minutes where the secret the whole time was racism.

The Haunting of Hill House: Genuinely loved this show. The first two episodes are a bit ‘meh’ and I kept watching mainly bc I was in the mood for a spooky show and then every episode from 3 on like totally blew my mind. It does scary/cozy in a really good way that I’m often looking for this time a year and is hard to find outside of Stephen King novels. It did what horror should do, work creatively and empathetically with the very real things we’re actually afraid of: death, loss and grief. That’s the whole reason horror was invented imho!

Bojack Horseman: I started watching this over the summer when I was sick and am about to start season 4. I watched the first episode a long time ago, thought it was boring/had already been done, and never returned to it. But then I kept hearing over and over that it’s like one of the great shows out there. So I tried again. Season 1 and 2 are a bit uneven, trying to find out if they’re going to be slap sticky or what, but punctuated by moments of painful brilliance. By S3 they lean hard into the deep sadness/meaninglessness at the heart of the show and the show totally blooms, funny and beautiful and sorrowful.

Maniac: I hated this first episode so much that I easily could have never watched it again. I just was like: I get it, he’s crazy but then they’ll be some dumb twist that will validate his delusional fantasies and justify the beliefs of millions of paranoid conspiracy theory obsessed sick people watching this and the world will be worse off for it. My BF was like, let’s try again. Episode 2 was better, but I still felt uncomfortable with it. And then idk what happened but I suddenly loved it? I miss the feeling of being in that story. It did different things than I thought it would. It handled mental health in way I ultimately thought was understanding and open. I liked the idea of two connected consciousnesses exploring their possible relationships in a shared dream space. I liked the focus on regret and grief. Although I am very over weird dystopias, I did like this weird dystopia. It wove together for me in a meaningful way.

summary: Sometimes I think about Villanelle’s deep-cut line “you’re romantic” when she talks to/about Konstantin in 1x08 and then I...
caption: Sometimes I think about Villanelle’s deep-cut line “you’re romantic” when she talks to/about Konstantin in 1x08 and then I remember the letters he wrote and sent Carolyn, which is something Villanelle did too with Anna, and I HAVE TO LAUGH. This is exactly why they get along, they play on the same level lmao

reblog.comment: Sometimes I think about Villanelle’s deep-cut line “you’re romantic” when she talks to/about Konstantin in 1x08 and then I remember the letters he wrote and sent Carolyn, which is something Villanelle did too with Anna, and I HAVE TO LAUGH. This is exactly why they get along, they play on the same level lmao

summary: “I guess what I’ve learned from playing Villanelle in Killing Eve is not to care so much. Especially with social media and...
body: “I guess what I’ve learned from playing Villanelle in Killing Eve is not to care so much. Especially with social media and stuff, you become so self-aware, but the one thing I loved about playing Villanelle was that she didn’t care what other people thought.”

reblog.comment: “I guess what I’ve learned from playing Villanelle in Killing Eve is not to care so much. Especially with social media and stuff, you become so self-aware, but the one thing I loved about playing Villanelle was that she didn’t care what other people thought.”

trail.content_raw: “I guess what I’ve learned from playing Villanelle in Killing Eve is not to care so much. Especially with social media and stuff, you become so self-aware, but the one thing I loved about playing Villanelle was that she didn’t care what other people thought.”
trail.content: “I guess what I’ve learned from playing Villanelle in Killing Eve is not to care so much. Especially with social media and stuff, you become so self-aware, but the one thing I loved about playing Villanelle was that she didn’t care what other people thought.”

summary: Villanelle strikes me as lonely, would you agree? “I think she is lonely. In episode one she says, ‘I just want someone to watch...
caption:
Villanelle strikes me as lonely, would you agree?

“I think she is lonely. In episode one she says, ‘I just want someone to watch movies with.’ I think that’s something we’ve all felt. We’re probably at a time in history where we have all this social media and you’d think it would bring people together more, and obviously it can, but it does exclude people and it can bring a lot of anxiety.” X

reblog.comment:

We’re probably at a time in history where we have all this social media and you’d think it would bring people together more, and obviously it can, but it does exclude people and it can bring a lot of anxiety.” X

tags: I met Rhianna Dhillon last week 'cos she was hosting a panel I was on
and yes of course i mentioned this killing eve q&a to her haha
anyway she's really friendly so that was great
title: Killing Eve | TV Q+A
excerpt: Multi-BAFTA winning writer Phoebe Waller-Bridge (Fleabag) is joined by Sandra Oh, Jodie Comer + Fiona Shaw to discuss Killing Eve, the eight-part series about a bored MI5 security officer who's tasked with tracking down fearsome assassin Villanelle. Listen for unique writing tips from Waller-Bridge herself + a step-by-step guide to finding your 'people.'
description:
I was gutted to have missed this preview screening in London last month, but thankfully there is now the chance to listen to the audio from the Q&A, hosted by the lovely Rhianna Dhillon.

There’s lots of interesting new details being brought up in the discussion on this panel, so I’d definitely recommend giving it a listen.

Notably, when asked by an audience member about the queer representation on the show:

“The moment Eve knows that Villanelle exists, a switch is turned on in her that hasn’t been turned on before, and then watching her work out what that is, and her attraction to her, and their chemistry together the first time they meet … we’d always talked about it as the moment they fall in love, and that was just a very natural, normal story point for us.” ~ Phoebe Waller-Bridge

“For me as well, it was something that I never questioned, it was just who she was, and I think that it’s resonated with people is lovely.” ~ Jodie Comer

“[There’s] the sexual power play between the two of them all the way through it … it’s not for anyone else, it’s just for them.” ~ Phoebe Waller-Bridge

(also I’m wondering how they’re gonna top how gay s1’s tralier was lol) but that plus the actual release date and the promo pics and all the s2 promo Sandra and Jodie are gonna do (separately and together). Next year is gonna be so fun.
